results.title: Chain reaction
results.brief_description: A silent film without subtext about one’s bad humour on others. An office manager whose wife spills the tea on his morning paper upsets his wife, their children and his subordinates at work. No other credits available.

results.title: Cervical cancer
results.creator_credit: Russell Kightley, A Ralph Rosenthal and Health Education Video Unit, Leicestershire Health Authority
results.brief_description: Details the structure of the cervix and explains why it is particularly vulnerable to external agents. Addresses the high incidence of cervical cancer and recommends preventative strategies.

results.title: Cerebral palsy: basic abilities
results.creator_credit: Spastic Centre of New South Wales
results.brief_description: Based on the Book “Cerebral Palsy - Basic Abilities - A plan for Training the Pre-School Child” the film carefully outlines the program used in New South Wales since 1963, in an attempt to develop visuomotor and perceptual learning skills.

results.title: Central Asia: crossroads of culture
results.creator_credit: M Raioumov and Tashkent Film Studios
results.brief_description: In the heart of Asia can be seen traces of a great civilization. The Central Asian region formed part of the Kisham Empire, comparable in greatness with that of the Romans. This film shows the relatively unknown cultural heritage of Central Asia. Made in co-operation with UNESCO and with the assistance of the National Commissions for UNESCO of Afghanistan, India, Iran, Pakistan and the USSR.

results.title: Celtic gold in Ireland
results.creator_credit: John Fitzmaurice Mills, Rex Roberts and National Museum of Ireland
results.brief_description: Shows some fine examples of prehistoric Celtic gold work, jewellery and other ornamental pieces, housed in the National Museum. The film also shows some of the places of historical interest where they were found in rural Ireland.

results.title: Cells and what they do
results.brief_description: The story of every living thing begins with the story of the living cell. Through a microscope, children see the parts of a plant cell, parts of an animal cell, the activity inside living cells, the process of cell division, and development of a fertilised egg. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Celebration: the Larwill Tapestry
results.brief_description: Established by the State Government of Victoria in 1976, the Victorian Tapestry Workshop has garnered itself an international reputation as a leader in the industry. In 1999 the Government decided to present a gift to the new Singapore Esplanade Theatre and visual artist David Larwill was selected to create a design that would be turned into a tapestry. This documentary covers the process of creating the tapestry, warping the loom, dying the wool, hitching on, interpreting the artwork, hitching off and the cutting off ceremony. Includes a biography of the artist and his work, as well as a brief spiel on the artist exchange program involving 3 Singapore artists, culminating in an exhibition at the Victorian College of the Arts. Sue Walker, Director, Victorian Tapestry Workshop is also interviewed on her involvement in the project.

results.title: Celebration of life: trees
results.creator_credit: Paul Fillinger and Paul Fillinger Productions
results.brief_description: The beauty and wonder of our natural environment gives cause for a celebration. The viewer joins a group of youngsters discovering and enjoying everything about trees and forests. It is a reminder of the people-nature activities that can be enjoyed. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.
